Name: Ko
QuoteDescript: "Young men often convert a hunting bow into a musical instrument" - Woodburn 1970, p.14
SpecificMat.3: Various animal skins- Zebra, Giraffe. Trophies.

Note: Kohl-Larsen text unavailabe in English. Unclear if wooden only or wood with traded iron. Used to kill hippos.

Name: //ho//ohoko
Note: First observed in 1890. Potentially earliest written record of Hadza.

Name: Shapoko
Note: Personal observation implies stitching. Probably bark thread. Also possibly ligament thread though bark confirmed in Lars Smith source. Thread type listed as supposition.

Name: Ato
Note: https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/object/E_Af1970-12-41

Name: Kimbakubi
Note: https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/object/E_Af1970-12-103
Mentioned by Marlowe but no record of the material. Could not find mention elsewhere, despite searching. Probably leather but little information to infer, thus excluded from analysis.
Wooden or shell needle both possible and plausible - but could find no evidence
Marlowe suggests potential alternative to glass beads. Also potentially used in tamdem in BM exhibit:
Modesty Apron. Leather material supposed but probable.

Name: ﻿A’untenakwete
Note: Used both for storage and transport. Alternative decorated beaded gourd used in symbolic contexts (storing fat, dancing). Often intricately carved in both contexts.
https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/object/E_Af1970-12-107
Marlowe suggests that 'the voice is the only native Hadza instrument' and  that others are borrowings.
Stone apparently unaltered, although it would preserve, it would probably not leave a clear archaeological signature

Name: Tl'atako
Note: Material not specified by Smith, but confirmed from personal observation.

Name: Ts'ako
Note: Assumed to be a spoon made of clam shell, rather than a spoon for eating clams!

QuoteDescript: "Little Hollow Sticks"

Name: Goyogoda
Note: Gennet skin hunt from belt in front of genitals

QuoteDescript: "The Eastern Hadza used to wear ostrich eggshell beads some years ago… the western hadza do… occasionally" - Woodburn 1970, p.50

Name: Tsiatoko
QuoteDescript: "They are worn by men or women as a treatment for eye pain, pain in the chest or painful pregnancy"

Note: Ju/'Hoansi record in Lee text substantially incomplete so excluded from analysis. Though retired, certain members of the Kalahari research group still very active and if of interest suggest contacting Richard or others as fuller record would be valuable.

QuoteDescript: "A thirteen-foot-long pole with an iron hook at the end, for probing springhare burrows and impaling the animal underground. The burrow is then excavated with a digging stick to retrieve the kill"

"A man surveys an area of bush for fresh tracks, then he lays down an unobtrustive line of brush to accustom the animal to cross at certain gaps. The snares are made of rope rope from local fibre plants with a delicate wooden trigger attached to a bent-over sapling."

Name: chi!kan
QuoteDescript: "Foremost among the carrying devices is the woman's caross…, a formidable one-piece combination garment-cum-carrying device that also does service as a sleeping blanket. The men manufacture these for the women from the hides of the female kudu, gemsbok, wildebeest or eland. This suede garment is worn draped over the wearer's back. Tied atthe waist wiith a leather thong, the lower half of the kaross conceals the wearer's backside and the upper half forms a pouch for carrying"

Name: /tausi
QuoteDescript: "A variety of stury leather bags are made from the skins of the steenbok and duiker. Both men and women wear small "handbags" over the shoulder and under the armpit for keeping handy tobacco, fire-making kits, sewing materials, and other items. The women's bags are brightly decorated with beadwork."

Name: /tausi
QuoteDescript: "A variety of stury leather bags are made from the skins of the steenbok and duiker. Both men and women wear small "handbags" over the shoulder and under the armpit for keeping handy tobacco, fire-making kits, sewing materials, and other items. The women's bags are brightly decorated with beadwork."
SpecificMat.2: Ostritch Egg beads (alternatively glass or plastic)

QuoteDescript: "For carrying a young infant, a mother employs a special leather baby carrier, tied around her waist and over her shoulders, that fits inside the kaross… This special baby carrier is lined with soft grasses and other absorband materials."

Name: !garo
QuoteDescript: "The carrying yoke is easily made from a rough wooden branch. Full bags, nets, bundles of meat, and haunches of freshly killed game are slung from either end, and the load is shouldered by a man for the long trips between camps"
"Men make an ingeniously intricate knotted net, called /wisi, for use as a carrying device. This wide-meshed net, 100 centimeters long and 40 centimeters aross, can be lined with long grass."
Note: Material not specified by lee in text, could plausibly be plant fibre as specified by Lee or alternatively processed sinew, as with G/ana net reported by .
Presence Assumed from photograph on Lee (1984) p. 41

Name: Ngoa
QuoteDescript: "Most of these iron blades are the products of the villager blacksmiths. The Mbuti obtain used ones from the villagers with whom they have close contacts."
Note: Blade is 20-40cm

Name: Koso
Note: Non-traditional machetes also attained through trade. Haft is 20cm
SpecificMat.1: S. longicaudata; J. pauciflorum; Antiaris welwitschii

Name: Lobo
Note: No mention of food processing in text but assumed to be used in butchery as axes are in so many other contexts
SpecificMat.1: Diospyros deltoidea, D. boala. Cola sciaphila, "Bukebukakula" (Unidentified)

Name: Topa
QuoteDescript: ﻿When the same blade is attached to the haft horizontally, it acts as an adze (Figure 4), which is of rather little use for the  Mbuti (compared with the nlachete and the axe), except when they occasionally make a canoe.
SpecificMat.1: Diospyros deltoidea, D. boala. Cola sciaphila, "Bukebukakula" (Unidentified)

Name: Ngoli
SpecificMat.1: Various types: Thaumatoccus deniellii; Marantochloa congensis; Eremospatha haullevilleana

Name: Mange
QuoteDescript: ﻿When the Mbuti catch monkeys (Cercopithecus sPP.), they use the tail skin for bow decoration, inserting one end ofthe bow shaft into the skin sheath ofthe tail.
Note: Also used as instrument
SpecificMat.1: Vepris louisii; Aidia micrantha; Diospyros spp.; Kalu (Unidentified)

Name: Appi
Note: ﻿45-50 cm long. Fletched with leaves.
SpecificMat.3: Penianthus longifolius; Garcinia ovalifolia; Bequaertiodendron lognipedicellata

Name: Sua/Mutali
Note: ﻿45-50 cm long. Typically not recovered
SpecificMat.1: Strychnos longicaudata; Acalypha neptunica; Raphia spp.

Name: Mutali
Note: Fishing and hunting; made of several ingredients
SpecificMat.1: Paraquentina nigrescens; ﻿E. guineese, lxora odorata, and P. africana; ﻿P. nigrescens.

Name: Ekingi
QuoteDescript: ﻿Mbuti's mortar is small, about 15-20 cm in diameter and 30-35 cm in height.
Note: Wood; hollowed tree trunk. Used both in food preperation and poison making
Woven Pressing Basket

Use Unconfirmed in Tanno source; ﻿For the fishing poison they use the Tetrapleura tetraptera legume, the "sakba" (unidentified) bark, or the leafy branches of Tephrosia vogelii, Elaeophorbia drupifera, "bukutu", "malombo", "mbi", and "pida" (all unidentified). They smash up any ofthese and throw it into the stream.

Name: Baba/Bolobolo
Note: Jiro argued that quivers and wrist protectors are ornamental and not used during actual hunting. Not coded s. evidence as not clear without context.

Name: Asuba
Note: Jiro argued that quivers and wrist protectors are ornamental and not used during actual hunting

Name: Ekonga
QuoteDescript: ﻿The spear is about 130-160 cm long and it consists ofa wooden shaft and an iron head, the largest of which is some 50 cm long and I5-cm wide. The lower end of the spearhead is of cylindrical form, into which the shaft is placed and bound
SpecificMat.1: ﻿Pancovia harmsiana; Diospyros sp.; Aidia lnicrantha; Vepris louisii; Cola sciaphila.

QuoteDescript: "This is also no more than a type of ornament."
Note: Claimed as ornamental

Name: Kuya
QuoteDescript: ﻿The length of a net employed by one Inan varies from about 40 to 100 m and its height is about 1.2 nl. The square mesh ofthe net is 5-7 cm long on one side. This net is wound up in a coil which is 2 m in circumference and carried across the shoulders.
Note: Optional nuts used as clappers

Name: Lele
Note: Hung around the neck of hunting dog. Not a hunting weapon sensu stricto but a hunting tool.

Name: Ekombi
QuoteDescript: ﻿A unique mark called the "ekombi" is also used, particularly in the case that the marker serves to clarify one's identity to anyone who finds it. The "ekombi" is a piece ofA. conferta leaf in which the totemic aninlal ('"inginiso") of his own clan is represented symbolically (Figure 10). Those who chance upon this mark can understand at a glance what clan the man who left the marker and when he passed there. If they find an "ekombi" at the foot ofa tree upon which bees nest, it tells that this honey has been already claimed by some person who found it before.
Note: Functions a little like a flag. Tagged as ritual due to symbolic meaning.

QuoteDescript: ﻿To gather root crops a digging stick is used. This is a simple stick 3-4 cm thick cut from shrubs. No particular species of shrub is used. Since Mbuti WOlnen always carry machetes, they can get digging sticks anywhere, so they need not carry them
Note: Disgarded more freely than Hadza twigs

Name: So
Note: Baskets may also be traded. Mbuti baskets woven from open mesh.
15-20cm diameter. Protects head when carrying basket
SpecificMat.1: Bark of ﻿Cynometra alexandri, Brachystegia laurentii, Gilbertiodendron dewevrei; Desplatzia dewevrei; Dicranolepis disticha; or stalks of ﻿Thaumatococcus  daniellii; Marantochloa congensis

Name: Ebimba
Note: Elaborately worked. Rarely made. "Villager-like handiwork"
Traditionally leather, now traded cloth

Name: Endu
QuoteDescript: ﻿The Mbuti's hut is semispherical about 2-3 m in diameter and 1.5 m in height, and is built by the woman.
SpecificMat.2: ﻿Thaumatococcuss daniellii; Fronds of ﻿Sclerosperma mannii or leaves of Gilbertiodendron dewevrei where T. d. lacking

Name: Amatobetobe
Note: May also trade with villiagers for another type of leaf mat "Kilako"

Name: Mbanga
QuoteDescript: The Mbuti (except the children) do not sit on the bare ground but sit on logs or Marantaceae leaves. The Mbutis' simplest chair is nlade of4-5 sticks 60-70 cm long and a coil ofany woody vine (Figure 15). This is called" mbanga", whose general meaning is short trees or sticks cut from trees or shrubs.

Name: Bakati
QuoteDescript: ﻿Further, they cut a multi-forked tree and lay it near the fire, and use it as a bench called "bakati"

Note: No mention of stone hearth
Called 'firebrand'. Used for illumination, starting fires or smoking termites out of their mounds for food.
Called 'firebrand'. Used for illumination, starting fires or smoking termites out of their mounds for food. Resin more effective than wood.

Name: Bakutu
QuoteDescript: ﻿This waistband, worked by women, is manufactured so elaborately through so many various processes that it appears to be one of the exceptional articles among the Mbuti's material culture.

Note: 9 Dyes in Total
SpecificMat.1: ﻿Chlorophora excelsa bark sap = yellow, (2) Isolona congolona bark sap = tan, (3) Agelaea lescrauwaettii bark sap = red, (4) Mukunaflagellipes leafsap = black, (5) Pterocarpus soyauxii powdered wood = red, (6) SiJnirestis welwitschii leafsap = black, (7) Landolphia jUlnellei bark sap = red, (8) Coffea afzelii = black, (9) Rothnzannia whitfieldii seed sap = black

Name: Banja
QuoteDescript: ﻿This percussion instrument is always used to lead the rhythm whenever songs are sung

Name: Alende
Note: Drumhead and straps to pull drum taught both made of duiker. According to one elder, villiager technology
SpecificMat.1: Duiker, for both strap and drumhead

Note: Hunting camps
SpecificMat.1: Log or butress of big tree

Name: Luma
Note: Pipes can also be made of mamboo, but usually wood. 12-15 pipes. Could also be a 'villager instrument' but villigers come to watch.

Name: Likembe
Note: Component parts undescribed so have used those of Bushman finger piano

Name: Malimo
Note: Molimo ritual

Name: Makata
QuoteDescript: ﻿This is a set of 7 sticks about 70-115 cm long, with lengths and thicknesses prepared so that each stick produces one sound of particular pitch different from the others when beaten with a short stick. Men
Note: Villiagers instrument
Made of dried fruit

Name: Sisa
QuoteDescript: Brings luck. Various plants used, typically burn. Full details on page 39,

Name: Kanga
QuoteDescript: ﻿two adult parties ofmen one side and women the other, they use the big and supple…

Note: Used and left on the spot
I suppose playing fetch is as much a game for people participating as it is for the dogs? I have chosen to code it this way, anyway, as not creating an n=1 category for dog toys!
Clay head then wood

Name: Molimo
Note: Alternative material for Molimo horn. Not elaborately decorated. Turnbull reports sound more important than appearance.
